meanings.definition: To put an end to; halt or stop.
meanings.sent1: She decided to kibosh the party because of the bad weather.
meanings.sent2: The teacher had to kibosh the noisy chatter in the classroom.
meanings.sent3: The cat tried to kibosh the game of fetch by stealing the ball.
meanings.sent4: His loud snoring kiboshed any chance of a peaceful night's sleep.
meanings.sent5: The sudden rain kiboshed our plans for a picnic in the park.

meanings.definition: Something that stops or halts a process or activity.
meanings.sent1: The red light at the intersection acted as a kibosh for the speeding car.
meanings.sent2: Lack of funding was the kibosh that prevented the project from moving forward.
meanings.sent3: The broken printer became the unexpected kibosh to their printing tasks.
meanings.sent4: Her strict diet was the kibosh on any hopes of indulging in dessert.
meanings.sent5: The flat tire put a kibosh on their road trip plans for the weekend.
